content: The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. Section 2110(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is an exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage. Section 2110(b)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to prohibit the exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage under a group health plan or health insurance. The amendment prohibits excluding children with access to high-cost coverage under a group health plan or health insurance. It also amends Titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act to replace "targeted low-income" with "targeted vulnerable." The Social Security Act is amended to replace "targeted low-income" with "targeted vulnerable" and to address children whose family income exceeds 200 percent of the poverty line. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2004. SEC. 3. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures to exceed expenditure limitations for outreach strategies under SCHIP. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states to exceed expenditure limitations for outreach strategies under SCHIP, with an increased FMAP by 5 percentage points for such expenditures. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states to exceed expenditure limitations for outreach strategies under SCHIP, with an increased FMAP by 5 percentage points for such expenditures, including presumptive eligibility for children under this title and under title XIX, and adoption of 12-month. The State provides presumptive eligibility and 12-month continuous eligibility for children under this title and title XIX, eliminating asset tests for eligibility. The State provides 12-month continuous eligibility for children under this title and title XIX, eliminating asset tests for eligibility. Automatic renewal of eligibility is ensured if no changes are reported in family income. The eligibility of children for assistance under title XIX and Medicaid is maintained even if no changes in family income are reported, subject to verification from State databases. The amendment (42 U.S.C. 1396a(l)) allows for enhanced Federal medical assistance percentage for outreach strategies targeting individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance under subsection (a)(10)(A). The State must implement similar outreach strategies for children under title XXI to qualify for the increased assistance. The enhanced FMAP can be increased under specific conditions, including outreach strategies for children under title XXI. These strategies include presumptive eligibility, 12-month continuous eligibility, elimination of asset tests, and passive renewal. The State can redetermine eligibility more frequently, eliminate asset tests, and allow for passive renewal of assistance under title XXI and title XXI. A conforming amendment to the Social Security Act is also made. The amendments made to the Social Security Act allow for changes in family income and relevant circumstances, subject to verification from State databases. The effective date of these amendments is October 1, 2004. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to increase funding for SCHIP and eliminates the SCHIP DIP. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2004. SEC. 5 imposes limitations on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not used up their available allotments. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2004, and do not prohibit states from establishing regular open enrollment periods for the submission of applications for child health assistance. Section 2107(e)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to include requirements for managed care under SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
